status_message: According to a statement issued by UN Spokesman Stéphane Dujarric, armed elements of both Morocco and Frente Polisario (Polisario Front) remain in close proximity to each other, a position they have been in since August 2016, monitored during daylight hours by the UN Mission for the Referendum in Western Sahara (MINURSO).

status_message: In a press statement issued in New York yesterday evening, the Council expressed grave concern at the recent reports of serious violations of international humanitarian law committed by local militia in that region, including unlawful recruitment and use of child soldiers, and of killings of civilians by members of Congolese security forces, known as FARDC, "all of which might constitute war crimes under international law."

status_message: As details on the destruction of and damage to Iraq's rich and diverse cultural heritage emerge, the United Nations cultural agency has appealed to the international community to help protect and revive the country's archaeological, religious and cultural sites for future generations.

status_message: "As you are aware, under the new approach, the UN is intensifying support to the Haitian government in building sound water, sanitation and health systems – the best long-term defence against cholera and other water-borne diseases – and also developing a support package to provide material assistance and support to Haitians most directly affected by cholera," a UN spokesperson said.

status_message: These data include the death toll reported this week from a boat with as many as 133 passengers on board that foundered off Az Zawiyah, near Tripoli on this past Sunday. According to an IOM source at the scene, the human smugglers stole the craft's engine and left the vessel drifting, telling passengers that authorities were en route to rescue them. "This is becoming a common tactic," said IOM Rome spokesman Flavio Di Giacomo. "But when you take an engine from a boat like this, you can no longer treat it as an 'incident.' It is homicide."

status_message: UN Emergency Relief Coordinator, Stephen O'Brien, has made a strong case for the need to urgently aid over 10 million people in Africa's Lake Chad Basin, saying "it is an investment for all of us," while highlighting its implications for the broader global security.  The remarks came ahead of a UN-led international conference for the Region, set to take place in Oslo, Norway, on 24 February. The Conference aims to seek funding support of $1.5 billion, in order to meet the urgent humanitarian needs of people affected by climatic events and the Boko Haram insurgency in the Region - mainly in Nigeria, Niger, Chad and Cameroon. status_message:
"Plastic pollution is surfing onto Indonesian beaches, settling onto the ocean floor at the North Pole, and rising through the food chain onto our dinner tables," Erik Solheim, the Executive Director of UNEP, said in a news release announcing its #CleanSeas campaign.

"We've stood by too long as the problem has gotten worse. It must stop."
link_name: 'Turn the tide on plastic' urges UN, as plastic particles in the seas now outnumber stars in our galaxy

status_message:
U Thant of Myanmar, served two terms at the helm of the United Nations. He was first appointed in an acting capacity in 1961 - in the aftermath of his predecessor's death - followed by two unanimous appointments for a full term, respectively, in 1962 and 1966. In this edition of Character Sketches, UN veteran Brian Urquhart  presents an up-close look into the decade-long tenure of the UN's third Secretary-General, with a detailed account of how U Thant steered the Organization through increasingly complex challenges at the peak of Cold War, with his belief in preventive diplomacy and pursuit of moderation.
Read more on UN News: http://bit.ly/2lOZN5S
link_name: U Thant - the third Secretary-General of the United Nations

"Famine is already a reality in parts of South Sudan. Unless we act now, it is only a matter of time until it affects other areas and other countries. We are already facing a tragedy; we must avoid it becoming a catastrophe," said the Secretary-General, stressing: "This is preventable if the international community takes decisive action."

The UN needs at least $4.4 billion by the end of March to avert a catastrophe, but only $90 million has actually been received so far – around two cents for every dollar needed, he said.

"This is my first visit to the region and the objective is to be able to consult the Government of Oman to see how I can be useful, recognizing that it's Member States and the people that have the leadership in bringing peace to the region," UN Secretary-General António Guterres told the press, following a meeting with Oman's foreign minister, Yusuf bin Alawi bin Abdullah.

"How I can be useful in supporting all those like Oman, who has always been in the first line of mediation trying to bring together the parties to the conflict and trying to make sure that peace is possible?" the UN chief said.
link_name: In Oman, UN chief Guterres seeks ways to help bring peace to Middle East

status_message: "Agriculture holds the key to solving two of the greatest problems now facing humanity: eradicating poverty and hunger, and contributing to maintaining the stable climatic conditions in which civilization can thrive," Food and Agriculture Organization Director-General José Graziano da Silva told a roundtable on climate change during the in Dubai.

status_message: "At a time of turbulence, radio provides an enduring platform to bring communities together," said UNESCO Director-General Irina Bokova in her message on the Day. "On the way to work, in our homes, offices and fields, in times of peace, conflict and emergencies, radio remains a crucial source of information and knowledge, spanning generations and cultures, inspiring us with the wealth of humanity's diversity, and connecting us with the world," she added.
link_name: 'Radio provides accessible, real-time medium to bridge divides,' UNESCO says on World Day

status_message:
"We are facing unprecedented needs, in an unprecedented number of locations, and these needs will increase during the upcoming lean season," said Eugene Owusu, the Humanitarian Coordinator for South Sudan.

Humanitarian organizations estimate that some 7.5 million people across South Sudan are now in need of humanitarian assistance and protection, including some 3.4 million people who had been forced to flee their homes since conflict began in December 2013.

After nearly four years in a senior UN role, outgoing Secretary-General's Envoy on Youth Ahmad Alhendawi  has reiterated the need for the world to work with young people. The UN Youth Envoy - who took up the role at the age of 27 - emphasized the potential and capacity of youth, while calling on the world to fully leverage "this asset," through further empowering and connecting the young people. status_message: Realizing that pulses – defined as edible dried seeds of plants in the legume family – are "small but powerful allies" in achieving the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), the UN General Assembly designated 2016 as the International Year of Pulses. Although the International Year has helped raise awareness globally of the many benefits of pulses, gains must be further strengthened to achieve the international community's new development goals, the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) said today.
link_name: 'Year of Pulses' closes with call to build on strong momentum among famers, private sector – UN

status_message: The number of food insecure people in Yemen has risen by three million in seven months, with an estimated 17.1 million people – more than two-thirds of the entire population of 27.4 million – now struggling to feed themselves, according to a joint assessment by three United Nations agencies. "The speed at which the situation is deteriorating and the huge jump in food insecure people is extremely worrying," said the Food and Agriculture Organization's (FAO) Representative in Yemen, Salah Hajj Hassan.

status_message: The UN Humanitarian Coordinator in Yemen, Jamie McGoldrick, has made an impassioned plea to the international community to assist Yemenis who are now having to make "life and death decisions" following 23 months of war. Mr. McGoldrick was speaking to the press in Geneva today, as the UN relief wing (OCHA) launched its 2017 humanitarian response plan for Yemen, seeking $2.1 billion funding support to aid 12 million people affected by the internal conflict. Read more on UN News: http://bit.ly/2loHRei

status_message: UN Emergency Relief Coordinator, Stephen O'Brien, has warned that there is "a real possibility" of famine in Yemen, as the UN's relief wing launched a $2.1 billion funding appeal - the largest-ever of its kind - to provide life-saving resources to the war-ravaged country. Highlighting the humanitarian situation in Yemen, where over 7 million people "don't know where their next meal is coming from", Mr O'Brien also urged all parties to the conflict to grant rapid and unhindered access, in order to provide the assistance that millions of Yemenis depend upon. Read more on UN News: http://bit.ly/2loHRei
link_name: UN aid chief warns against imminent threat of famine in Yemen

status_message: Despite some gains, "Libyans are not in a position to address the root causes of divisions," Martin Kobler, the Secretary-General Special Representative and head of the UN Support Mission in Libya (UNSMIL), told the UN Security Council, stressing that some important decisions must be taken, including on possible amendments to the political agreement, on ways to form a strong army and police force, and on how best to utilize the revenues from oil and gas exports for the benefit of all Libyans and end the dire humanitarian situation in the country.
link_name: Libyans must make 2017 the 'year of decisions,' UN envoy tells Security Council

status_message: The world can never overlook the importance of helping children who are affected by armed conflict, given that the future of every nation and humanity is at stake, UN envoy Leila Zerrougui has said. Ms. Zerrougui's remarks come as the UN marks the 20th anniversary of the mandate of her office as the Special Representative of the Secretary-General for Children and Armed Conflict. Speaking to UN News on the occasion, Ms. Zerrougui outlined the global achievements made during the past two decades, in terms of raising awareness about the plight of children in armed conflict, while noting the challenges faced in aiding children caught in conflict settings, which now oftentimes transcend national  borders. status_message: Reforming the International Criminal Court (ICC) is necessary in order to strengthen its ability to uphold international justice, according to UN Special Adviser on the Prevention of Genocide, Adama Dieng. Speaking to UN News about his newly-released Op-ed in The East African,  titled, "Why Withdrawing from the Rome Statute Undermines International Justice for Everyone," Mr. Dieng said withdrawing from the ICC will not solve problems, but rather it is important to encourage dialogue amongst the public, private sector and civil society in order to ensure the Court remains strong and relevant. In the Op-ed, Mr. Dieng responds to questions following three African countries' (South Africa, Burundi and The Gambia) withdrawal from the ICC last October. Read more on UN News: http://bit.ly/2li3CAF

status_message: UN High Commissioner for Refugees Filippo Grandi said that the recent decision by the United States to suspend its refugee resettlement programme would negatively impact the most vulnerable individuals. "Resettlement means taking refugees from places like Lebanon, where they are already refugees, selecting the most vulnerable and taking them to other places," he said. "If we weaken that programme, as has been done in the United States, this is a very dangerous weakening of the international solidarity for refugees."

status_message: United Nations Secretary-General António Guterres said in video message that it would be a dangerous error to think of the Holocaust as simply the result of the insanity of a group of criminal Nazis. "On the contrary, the Holocaust was the culmination of millennia of hatred, scapegoating and discrimination targeting the Jews, what we now call anti-Semitism," he emphasized, adding that tragically and contrary to the international community's resolve, anti-Semitism continues to thrive.
link_name: Honouring Holocaust victims, UN chief Guterres pledges to battle anti-Semitism, all forms of hatred

status_message:
During World War II, Chiune Sugihara, a Japanese diplomat posted as an acting consul in Lithuania, disobeyed instructions from his own Government and issued visas for Jews fleeing Nazi persecution. Sugihara issued more than 2,000 transit visas to Jewish refugees in 1940, continuing to sign the travel documents even after the Japanese consulate was closed down and until his train pulled away from the station. Many of the visas were for entire families. As a result, it is estimated that Sugihara saved 6,000 Jews. 

For more, http://bit.ly/2k98ffb #HolocaustRembrance
link_name: FEATURE: Story of Japan's 'Schindler' offers lessons for tackling contemporary xenophobia

status_message: OCHA notes that Afghanistan remains one of the most dangerous, and most violent, crisis-ridden countries in the world. The $550 million Humanitarian Response Plan dedicates $240 million to interventions to assist refugees and returnees.

status_message: "Nothing justifies the use of siege and the untold suffering that it unleashes on children. The children of Syria have already paid the highest price for a war that is not of their making," said Geert Cappelaere, UNICEF's Regional Director.
link_name: Syria: UNICEF calls for unimpeded aid access for children in besieged Deir Ez Zor

status_message: International talks to extend the ceasefire in Syria started today in the Kazakh capital of Astana, with the United Nations Special Envoy said the ceasefire can be solidified if a mechanism to oversee and implement it is created.
link_name: At talks in Astana, UN envoy on Syria urges mechanism to oversee ceasefire

status_message:
"Millions of small family farmers need technical and financial assistance to be more resilient and adapt to the impacts of climate change," said José Graziano da Silva, the Director-General of the UN Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO).

"They must be able to stay on their land, produce their own food and also have access to markets."

Read more: http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=56019
link_name: UN agency urges support for small farmers to help them not just get by, but thrive and feed others

status_message:
In a joint declaration late yesterday, UN, ECOWAS and AU pledged to work with the Government of The Gambia to "ensure that it assures and ensures the dignity, respect, security and rights of former President Jammeh, as a citizen, a party leader and a former Head of State as provided for and guaranteed by the 1997 Gambian Constitution and other Laws of The Gambia."

Read more: http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=56018
link_name: The Gambia: UN, ECOWAS, AU hail 'goodwill' of former President Jammeh; commit to work for his dignity and security

status_message:
On this day in 1909, the UN's second Secretary-General - U Thant - was born.

The Burmese diplomat succeeded Dag Hammarskjöld following the latter's untimely death while on a peace mission in Africa, and served at the helm of the world body from 1961 to 1971.

Coming this week: a personal perspective on Mr. Thant's life from @UN veteran Sir Brian Urquhart! bit.ly/2jMFbd1

Top stories from the UN News Service, during the week of 16 - 20 January 2017, featuring: combatting anti-Muslim discrimination and hatred; launch of World Economic Situation and Prospects 2017; first-ever UN World Data Forum, and concerns over political standoff in The Gambia.
"Young children are in real danger because of the severe weather," UNICEF's Basil rodriques said regarding migrant children in Europe. http://bit.ly/2k9HMug

One day after United Nations Security Council endorsed the recognition, by ECOWAS, of Adama Barrow as President of The Gambia, UNHCR, the UN Refugee Agency today said that around 45,000 people have already arrived in neighbouring Senegal, fleeing the Gambia.
The latest reports indicate that Regional West African troops have entered the country amidst concerns over former President Jammeh's refusal to step down. President Adama Barrow was sworn in yesterday at the Gambian Embassy in Dakar, Senegal. http://bit.ly/2jhe86D

"The tetrapylon was an architectural symbol of the spirit of the encounter and openness of Palmyra – and this is also one of the reasons why it has been destroyed. Its position and shape are unique in ancient architecture and testified to the specificity of Palmyrene identity, as a source of pride and dignity for all Syrians today," UNESCO Director-General Irina Bokova said
link_name: UN confirms destruction of sites in Palmyra, other ancient Syrian cities

status_message: The United Nations and the countries in Latin America and the Caribbean have together crafted a blueprint for making the agriculture, food and nutritional security sectors more disaster-proof so the region can tackle hunger in a sustainable manner. "This transition cannot be achieved without the development of sectoral measures for disaster risk management involving technologies, productive practices and sustainable use of natural resources, as well as considerable changes in terms of governance, legislation, policies and public and private investment," said Jorge Meza, chief forestry officer of the UN Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO).
link_name: UN-backed disaster risk reduction guidelines to help tackle hunger in Latin America

status_message: According to the Supplementary Appeal for the South Sudan Situation, launched by the Office of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), over three million people are estimated to benefit from the agency's interventions by 31 December 2017. These numbers do not include local populations in host communities who – themselves suffering from food insecurity and limited access to basic social services and infrastructure – would also benefit from humanitarian interventions under the agency's inclusive support strategy.
link_name: UN agency revises funding requirements to tackle Africa's worst displacement crisis

status_message: UN rights expert welcomes US decision to lift most sanctions on Sudan, urges the Sudanese authorities "to intensify their efforts to enhance peace and stabilization efforts and uphold human rights." http://bit.ly/2jDRaKf

"Properly managed, wastewater can be used safely to support crop production – directly through irrigation or indirectly by recharging aquifers – but doing so requires diligent management of health risks through adequate treatment or appropriate use," the Food and Agricultural Organization said today.
link_name: UN agency eyes recycling wastewater for large-scale farming

status_message: "Without the private sector we will not have the necessary innovation, we will not have the necessary capacity to discover new markets, new products, new services and to be able to develop new areas in the economy," UN Secretary-General António Guterres said, adding also that only the private sector can create enough jobs to stabilize societies.
link_name: At Davos economic forum, UN chief Guterres calls business 'best allies' to curb climate change, poverty

status_message: The Council strongly condemned former President Jammeh's 9 December statement rejecting the official election results and the takeover of the Independent Electoral Commission by the Gambian Armed Forces on 13 December 2016, as well as the attempt by the Parliament on 18 January 2017 to extend President Jammeh's term for three months beyond his current mandate, which ends today.
link_name: Gambia: Security Council backs regional efforts to ensure peaceful transfer of power to Barrow
United Nations News Centre's cover photo

status_message: Nearly 360 million people, or 58 per cent of the inhabitants of the region, are overweight with the highest rates observed in the Bahamas at 69 per cent, Mexico at 64 per cent and Chile at 63 per cent, according to a news release on the Panorama of Food and Nutrition Security in Latin America and the Caribbean report, compiled by the UN Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) and the Pan American Health Organization (PAHO).
link_name: Processed foods drive surge in obesity rates in Latin America and Caribbean – UN-backed report

status_message:
"An exhausted civilian population is still trapped, with no escape, we are still unable to reach hundreds and hundreds of thousands," United Nations Senior Adviser on Syria Jan Egeland told the press in Geneva today, emphasizing that "in terms of humanitarian access, the cessation of hostilities period has been a disappointment."

Read more: http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=56005
link_name: Syria: Ceasefire a 'disappointment' for aid access; UN envoy invited to Astana peace talks

status_message:
The United Nations has today announced that its Special Envoy for Syria, Staffan de Mistura will participate in the meeting about the situation in Syria, to be convened at the end of January in Astana, Kazakhstan, by the Islamic Republic of Iran, the Russian Federation and Turkey. 

The Special Adviser to the Envoy Jan Egeland said that he is "glad" that the three countries will "indeed push as guarantors for Astana for the parties, including the government," to stop the present practice of denying access to "courageous humanitarians who are able and willing to go to places with relief." 
Read more: http://bit.ly/2jDGP0n

"Unless more resources are provided, there is still a very real risk of a 'lost generation' of Syrian children, deprived of the skills they will one day need to rebuild their country," said UNICEF Deputy Executive Director Justin Forsyth, speaking after a visit to southern Turkey.

According to UNICEF, nearly half a million Syrian refugee children are currently enrolled in schools across Turkey. But over 40 per cent of children of school-going age – or 380,000 child refugees – are still missing out on an education, despite a more than 50 per cent increase in enrolment since last June.
link_name: Turkey: UNICEF cites risk of 'lost generation' of Syrian children despite enrolment increase

status_message: "We are especially concerned about vulnerability and needs of migrant and refugee children especially women and girls and this initiative is exactly what is needed," explained chief IOM spokesperson Leonard Doyle, highlighting the Plan's particular emphasis on addressing the specific needs of refugee and migrant children and those of women and girls.
link_name: UN agencies, partners launch new plan to address plight of refugees and migrants in Europe

status_message: United Nations Under-Secretary-General for UN Peacekeeping Operations, Hervé Ladsous has paid tribute to victims of the suicide attack which happened Wednesday in Mali. Addressing the Security Council, Mr. Ladsous regretted the lack of progress on the Agreement for Peace and Reconciliation in Mali, underscoring the importance of the agreement in reaching peace and reconciliation in the country. http://bit.ly/2k6L2uL

Earlier today, UN Under-Secretary-General for Political Affairs Jeffrey Feltman briefed the Security Council concerning the Iranian nuclear issue. In his remarks, Mr. Feltman highlighted the "steady" progress and cooperation, since the international community embarked on implementing the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) on 16 January 2016. Mr. Feltman also called for the world's sustained political will to facilitate the implementation, with the aim of ensuring that Iran's nuclear programmes are "exclusively peaceful" in nature. http://bit.ly/2jAzj6G
link_name: UN political affairs chief reaffirms will to resolve Iranian n...

status_message: The first-ever United Nations World Data Forum concluded today with the launch of a global plan that outlines a vision and a "to-do" list for better data to improve people's lives, including through new ideas, solutions and strengthened collaboration in the field of statistics.
link_name: UN forum wraps up in South Africa with a call for better data to improve people's lives

status_message: "Families from east Aleppo are in desperate need of humanitarian assistance such as food and non-food items; and registration of birth, death, marriage and family papers and other legal services, Ali Al-Za'tari, announcing the allocation of $19 million from the Syria Humanitarian Fund to sustain immediate life-saving and early recovery assistance for people in war-ravaged Aleppo.
link_name: Top UN humanitarian official in Syria allocates $19 million for emergency response in Aleppo

status_message: "The results of the assessment show the very positive impact of our collective efforts in the aftermath of Hurricane Matthew, but also the pressing need to continue and redirect assistance to new areas with higher levels of food insecurity, as well as initiate recovery interventions," said Ronald Tran Ba Huy, WFP's Representative in Haiti.
link_name: Three months after Hurricane Matthew, 1.5 million Haitians face hunger – UN agencies report

status_message: "2016 was an extreme year for the global climate and stands out as the hottest year on record," said WMO Secretary-General Petteri Taalas, emphasizing that long-term indicators of human-caused climate change reached new heights last year and carbon dioxide and methane concentrations hit record highs.
link_name: 2016 was the hottest year ever recorded – UN weather agency

status_message: Welcoming the commutation of United States army officer Chelsea Manning's 35-year sentence for leaking classified military documents, a United Nations independents human rights expert today called on Governments to recognize the contributions of whistleblowers and pardon those serving prison sentences.
link_name: Following Chelsea Manning's commutation, UN expert urges pardons for other whistleblowers

status_message: "We condemn with the utmost firmness this cowardly and ignoble attack which constitutes a direct attack on the peace process," Under-Secretary-General for Peacekeeping Operations, Hervé Ladsous, told the UN Security Council.
link_name: Mali: UN condemns suicide bombing of Gao military camp as 'direct attack' on peace process

status_message: According to the International Organization for Migration (IOM), up to 12,000 migrants, every month, are arriving onto the shores of the Gulf of Aden country with hopes of making their way to Saudi Arabia.
link_name: Yemen: Ongoing humanitarian crisis adding to migrants woes, says UN migration agency

status_message: Resolutions and communiques alone will not achieve a just and lasting peace. What is required is action, first and foremost by the parties themselves," Nickolay Mladenov, the UN Special Coordinator for the Middle East Peace Process, told the Security Council today.
link_name: At Security Council, senior UN envoy cautions against 'unilateral' action in Middle East

status_message:
"Gender statistics are critical for setting priorities, planning interventions and assessing their impacts," Purna Sen, the Director of Policy Division at UN Women, told a panel discussion. "They can put a spotlight on inequality and women and girls who are left behind."

Emily Courey-Pryor, Executive Director of Data2X, who moderated the discussion, said that "we will only be able to truly promote gender equality, alleviate poverty, and advance development progress if we improve gender data."
link_name: At Cape Town Forum, UN Women and partners seek ways to close gender data gaps

status_message:
"Under the current growth trajectory and assuming no decline in income inequality, nearly 35 per cent of the population in [least developed countries] may remain in extreme poverty by 2030," read a news release today announcing the report.

Further, noting the urgency of efforts rectify the situation, Lenni Montiel, Assistant Secretary-General for Economic Development at the United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (DESA) called for "redoubling the efforts to bring the global economy back on a stronger and more inclusive growth path and create an international economic environment that is conducive to sustainable development."

Read more: https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=55988
link_name: Modest economic growth not an indication of revived global demand – UN report

status_message:
Weak global growth continues to linger, posing a challenge to the implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development,  a top United Nations economist has said, adding that the global gross product is projected to expand just 2.2 per cent in 2016, the slowest rate of growth since the Great Recession of 2009. 

Speaking to UN News ahead of the launch of the World Economic Situation and Prospects 2017, United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (DESA) Assistant Secretary-General Lenni Montiel called for "deeper" international cooperation and stronger, "concerted policy effort" to stimulate investment and productivity. He also reiterated the importance of policies that support clean energy technology and combatting climate change, which impact economies in many countries. #WESP2017 #UNDESA70 #GlobalGoals

"Last year the Government of Ethiopia, with the support of international donors and humanitarian partners, was able to mount the biggest drought response operation in global history. Today we need that partnership once again as we face a new drought, with 5.6 million in need of urgent assistance," said Commissioner Mitiku Kassa, Head of the National Disaster Risk Management Commission.

"Humanitarian partners stand ready to support the Government in addressing the needs of those Ethiopians affected by this new drought," said the UN Resident and Humanitarian Coordinator Ahunna Eziakonwa-Onochie.
link_name: Ethiopia: UN-backed humanitarian appeal launched, seeking $948 million in 2017

status_message:
"Discrimination diminishes us all. It prevents people – and societies – from achieving their full potential," said United Nations Secretary-General António Guterres in a video message to a high-level event on combating anti-Muslim discrimination and hatred.

"In times of insecurity, vulnerable communities that look different become convenient scapegoats," he added, calling on everyone to resist cynical efforts that try to divide communities and "portray neighbours as 'the other'."

#no2hatred #jointogether
link_name: Diversity 'is richness, not a threat,' UN chief Guterres tells forum on combatting anti-Muslim discr

status_message: The Humanitarian Response Plan for Somalia for 2017 comes against a backdrop of deteriorating humanitarian situation in the country: expanding drought conditions have left thousands of Somalis facing severe food and water shortages. Overall, some 5 million people are in need of relief and about 3.3 million people lack access to emergency health services and require improved access to water, sanitation and hygiene.
link_name: Somalia: Early action only way to avert another catastrophe, says senior UN relief official

status_message: A top United Nations statistician has stressed the need to organise and set rules for the important increase of data that the world is currently confronted with. Stefan Schweinfest, Director of UN Stats from the Department of Economic and Social Affairs, was speaking at the World Data Forum in Cape Town, South Africa on Monday during a panel discussion. Mr. Schweinfest said one of the goals of the Forum was to bring data stakeholders together in order to create dialogue and work to create a new statistics architecture http://bit.ly/2jStrCs

Academy Award-winning actor Forest Whitaker received the 2017 Crystal Award in Davos, Switzerland, ahead of this year's World Economic Forum. Mr Whitaker was honoured for his dedication to peacebuilding and conflict-resolution, as the special envoy for UN's cultural agency, UNESCO. In an earlier interview with UN News, Mr. Whitaker talked about his ideals and work - through various institutions - which serve to promote peace and reconciliation across the world's conflict-torn regions. http://bit.ly/2iAllgQ
link_name: UNESCO envoy highlights importance of partnerships in conflict...

status_message: "Indeed, your achievements and the challenges you face sit against a disturbing background of ongoing violations of the rights of children," Kate Gilmore, Deputy High Commissioner for Human Rights, said at the opening in Geneva of the 74th session of the Committee on the Rights of the Child, which will run through 3 February 2017.
link_name: Ongoing violations of child rights highlighted as UN monitoring body opens annual session

status_message: "In what is already a tragic start to 2017 on the Mediterranean Sea,"  Vincent Cochetel, Regional Refugee Coordinator for the Refugee Crisis in Europe was "heartened to see the first priority of saving lives in action through the rescue efforts of the Italian Coastguard and Frontex. http://bit.ly/2izFgg0

The Handbook on the Management of Violent Extremist Prisoners and the Prevention of Radicalization to Violence in Prisons, launched today by UNODC - United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime aims to strengthen key components of prison management, including training of prison staff, risk management and rehabilitation efforts.

"It also cautions against generalized assumptions regarding a very complex topic, as well as against 'quick fix solutions' when it comes to the management of violent extremist prisoners," said the UN agency in a news release announcing the manual.
link_name: New UN manual aims to address management of violent extremists in prison settings

status_message: "Success requires that all communities represented in this room fulfill a critical role and find ways to work together and create partnerships and synergies," Wu Hongbo, the UN Under-Secretary-General for Economic and Social Affairs, said at the opening plenary of the UN World Data Forum under way in the South African city of Cape Town.
link_name: UN Data Forum explores ways to improve and modernize national statistical systems

status_message: While efforts to fully implement a ceasefire in Syria continue, senior United Nations humanitarian officials today appealed for immediate, unconditional, and safe access to reach the children and families who are still cut off from relief aid across the Middle Eastern country.
link_name: 'We must not let 2017 repeat tragedies of 2016 for Syria' – joint statement by top UN aid officials

status_message:
Francesca Grum, Chief, Social and Housing Statistics Section, leads efforts to develop international standards and methodology to produce statistics on gender equality. For instance, her Section compiles data on asset ownership by women, statistics on violence against women, and time women spend on unpaid work, such as childcare and domestic chores. 

"These are critical dimensions of women's empowerment, and data will be needed to ensure the achievement of SDGs, including Goal 5 on gender equality," she said.  Read more at http://bit.ly/2jmtGJq

"The Forum comes at a crucial time for strengthening data and statistical capacity globally. Countries all around the world are mobilizing to carry out the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, which they adopted at a UN summit two years ago," Wu Hongbo, the UN Under-Secretary-General for Economic and Social Affairs, told a press conference at the opening of the Forum. "To do so, it is essential to have accurate, reliable, timely and disaggregated data," he added.
link_name: UN Data Forum opens in South Africa to harness power of data for sustainable development

status_message: Here is a rundown highlighting key events coming up at the UN next week, starting 15 January 2016, including the UN World Data Forum, Secretary-General Guterres' message on combatting anti-Muslim discrimination and hatred, World Economic Situation and Prospects 2017, and the 2017 World Economic Forum in Davos.

The first-ever UN Global Data Forum is set to kick off in Cape Town, South Africa. Speaking to UN News ahead of this ground-breaking forum, UN Under-Secretary-General Wu Hongbo highlighted the vital role that data, or statistics, can play in the realisation of Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Mr. Wu also noted that the Cape Town Forum aims to rally support from the international community, so as to better help developing countries - especially the least developed countries - to bridge their data gap, through partnerships and capacity building. http://bit.ly/2jvPVK8
link_name: UN DESA chief underscores the critical role of data in achievi...

status_message: Top stories from United Nations News during the week of 9 to 13 January 2017, featuring UN Secretary-General's first address to the Security Council, Opening of the Conference on Cyprus in Geneva and the latest ILO report on Employment and Social Outlook.

"When you are statisticians, you are not normally on the forefront of news," says Stefan Schweinfest, Director of the Statistics Division in the UN Department of Economic and Social Affairs (DESA), ahead of the first-ever United Nations World Data Forum in Cape Town, South Africa, which aims to create partnerships and initiatives that harness the power of data for the public good and for the implementation of the new global development goals.

However, he said, the work of statisticians, characterised as not being "the most sexy profession," is drawing a lot of attention in the context of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, which was adopted at a high-level summit in September 2015 and includes 17 goals and 169 targets.
link_name: FEATURE: Number crunchers in the spotlight ahead of UN World Data Forum

status_message: As Secretary-General António Guterres stressed the importance to find a "sustainable solution for the Republic of Cyprus and for the communities of the Republic of Cyprus" at the Conference on Cyprus in Geneva, discover in this short explainer video what the United Nations has been doing since 1964 in Cyprus.

Amid a "rising tide of democracy" across the African continent, the United Nations must continue to support regional efforts to ensure that the Gambia's recent election results were upheld, stressed the Organization's senior official in West Africa and the Sahel as he briefed the Security Council this morning.
link_name: Amid progress in West Africa and the Sahel, UN envoy warns of region's political challenges

Mr. Wu also noted that the Cape Town Forum aims to rally support from the international community, so as to better help developing countries - especially the least developed countries - to bridge their data gap, through partnerships and capacity building. "The last days have been a watershed moment for the Cyprus negotiations," Espen Barth Eide, the UN Special Adviser Cyprus, told reporters today.

"I think that there is a momentum now. Larger political developments remind us that it is probably, or quite surely, very important to use these days as effectively as we can and in as constructive spirit as possible."
link_name: International conference is 'watershed moment' for Cyprus negotiations – UN envoy

status_message: Amid new crises that arise elsewhere in the world and attract the attention of donors because of their acuity and their dreadful effects on civilian populations, a strong advocacy campaign is under way to ensure that the Central African Republic is not a forgotten or neglected crisis.

status_message:
"Space-based data and infrastructure can really support the fulfillment of the Sustainable Development Goals in different ways: for example, through images or information services or applications…We have so many topics relevant to the 17 SDGs, including gender equality. Really, we can do a lot in helping the world become a better world."

– Simonetta Di Pippo, UN Office for Outer Space Affairs
link_name: INTERVIEW: Space technology can help create a better world – Simonetta Di Pippo, UN Office for Outer Space Affairs

status_message: "We have started to understand that access to space is really important for developing countries to be part of this space community and to get more and more benefits from being part of this process," said Simonetta Di Pippo, Director of the United Nations Office for Outer Space Affairs
link_name: Space technology can help create a better world, says top UN space official

status_message: World Food Programme's #HotDinnerData reveals that people in the developing world pay as much as 100 times more for a basic plate of food than those who live in wealthier nations. In the most extreme circumstances – for example, in regions under conflict – the cost can be 300 times higher.
link_name: UN data reveals huge disparities in cost of a hot meal; the poor are likely to pay far more than the rich

status_message: The health, hygiene and protection needs of women and girls displaced in Aleppo are staggering, the United Nations has observed, voicing concern for civilians in the Syrian city that has endured intense fighting for about four years.
link_name: UN agencies assess dire hygiene, protection needs for women in Syria's war-ravaged Aleppo

status_message: " I am heartened that seven years after this tragedy, Haiti has found its path to political stability with the election of a new president and parliament, and I stand with the people of Haiti, and all of our colleagues around the world, in honouring the memory of those we lost but whom are never forgotten," said Dr. David Nabarro, Special Adviser to the Secretary-General.
link_name: Paying tribute to earthquake victims, UN adviser says 'Haiti on its path to political stability'

status_message: "Humanitarian aid is essential for the survival of the thousands of families displaced by Mosul operations who have left everything behind to save their own lives," said Thomas Lothar Weiss, the Chief of the UN International Organization for Migration (IOM) operations in Iraq.
link_name: Iraq: Thousands displaced from Mosul in 'desperate' need of life-saving aid, UN agency reports

status_message: "The hard-won laws and principles of the Universal Declaration for Human Rights are increasingly imperiled, and the business leaders gathering in Davos next week have a key role to play to stem this terrible tide and to insist upon respect for human rights in the States where they operate," said UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Zeid Ra'ad Al Hussein in a news release issued by his Office (OHCHR).
link_name: UN rights chief urges executives gathering in Davos to stand up for rights

status_message: "We are facing the twin challenge of repairing the damage caused by the global economic and social crisis and creating quality jobs for the tens of millions of new labour market entrants every year," said UN International Labour Organization (ILO) Director-General Guy Ryder.
link_name: World's jobless to rise amid economic uncertainty, growing inequality – UN labour report

status_message: A new United Nations report "World Employment and Social Outlook – Trends 2017 " says that global unemployment is to increase by 3.4 million in 2017.  Launching the report, the Director-General of the International Labour Organization (ILO) Guy Ryder said that despite the "marginal improvement" in economic growth, it is not enough to stop unemployment, adding that creating qualitative jobs and combatting inequality are crucial. Mr Ryder called on the international community to "make greater efforts" to pull the global economy out of the after effects of the crisis of 2008 and make sure that international cooperation and focus remains on the jobs crisis.

While the ceasefire in Syria is largely holding, the United Nations envoy for the country cautioned today that the truce may be under threat as clashes in villages in the Wadi Barada valley have damaged water infrastructure and left more than five million people in and around Damascus facing water shortages.
link_name: Syria ceasefire holding amid rising concerns about aid delivery and Damascus water supply – UN envoy

status_message: "This measles vaccination campaign is an emergency intervention to protect more than 4 million children against a highly contagious and sometimes deadly disease," said Dr. Wondimagegnehu Alemu, Country Representative of the UN World Health Organization (WHO). "Massive disruption to health services in conflict-affected areas for many years has deprived these children of essential childhood vaccinations. In addition, many of them have severe malnutrition, making them extremely vulnerable to serious complications and death from measles," he added.
link_name: UN-backed campaign to help vaccinate millions of children against measles in north-east Nigeria

status_message: UN-facilitated International Conference on Cyprus started today in Geneva, chaired by Secretary-General António Guterres. During a break, Mr. Guterres - accompanied by the Greek Cypriot and Turkish Cypriot leaders - addressed reporters, underscoring that the conference was seeking "a solid and sustainable solution," not "a quick fix" for the Republic of Cyprus. Mr. Guterres also expressed the world body's commitment to guaranteeing the results that could be achieved from the conference. http://bit.ly/2ikE0NG
link_name: Secretary-General Guterres: "We are looking for a solid and su...

status_message: Amid a global shortage of injectable inactivated polio vaccines (IPV), a new inoculation regimen, employed by governments in the South-East Asian region, involving two fractional vaccine doses – each about a fifth of a full dose – provides the same level of protection against all polioviruses as does one full dose, the United Nations World Health Organization South-East Asia Region - WHO SEARO said today.
link_name: UN agency hails new polio vaccination regimen in South-East Asia that curbs impact on global supply

status_message: "Civilians remain exposed to significant sources of insecurity such as inter-communal conflict and criminality, including the activities of armed militias," the Under-Secretary-General for Peacekeeping Operations, Hervé Ladsous, told the Council presenting the latest report of the Secretary-General on the situation in Darfur.
link_name: Inter-communal tensions in Darfur threaten return of millions of displaced people, Security Council told

status_message: Speaking at a press conference during a recess, the new UN chief said "it is my hope that there will be a breakthrough" that the people of Cyprus deserve and the world needs. "We are facing so many situations of disasters. We badly need a symbol of hope. I strongly believe Cyprus can be the symbol of hope at the beginning of 2017," he added.
"When Da'esh is defeated in Iraq, that's a military success, but the humanitarian crisis is a legacy – it just keeps going," UN Humanitarian Coordinator Lise Grande.
link_name: Humanitarian crisis in Mosul could go on beyond Iraq military operations, senior UN official warns

status_message: The head of UN Peacekeeping Hervé Ladsous has urged the international community to push for a swift endorsement of the so-called 31 December political accord in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and to put in place a transitional government of national unity. Mr. Ladsous was addressing members of the Security Council, who met on Wednesday to discuss the situation in the vast African country. He said the UN Secretariat and the UN Mission in DRCongo (MONUSCO) remain committed to working in support of the accord and the Congolese, adding that the mission will continue its efforts to "counter the destabilizing activities of armed groups".

Despite the logistical challenges and political uncertainty following the Colombian plebiscite last October, the country has a host of "solid assets" that can help to advance its peace process, UN envoy for Colombia, Jean Arnault, told the Security Council earlier today. Mr. Arnault was briefing the Council on the work of the UN Mission in Colombia, and the progress made in the implementation of the historic Peace Agreement reached last year. In addition to the resolve of the Colombian leaders and people, Mr. Arnault stressed that unanimous support from international community - including that of the Council - will remain "a very significant success factor" in advancing the Colombian peace deal. http://bit.ly/2iHPM5y
link_name: UN envoy lauds 'solid assets' in Colombian peace process

status_message: "After years of disappointing global growth, we are encouraged to see stronger economic prospects on the horizon," World Bank Group President Jim Yong Kim said in a news release. "Now is the time to take advantage of this momentum and increase investments in infrastructure and people. This is vital to accelerating the sustainable and inclusive economic growth required to end extreme poverty," he added.
link_name: World Bank sees 'moderate' pick up for global economy in 2017 despite weak investment

status_message: Espen Barth Eide, the UN Special Advisor Cyprus who has been facilitating talks between the Greek Cypriot and Turkish Cypriot leaders, told reporters: "We are on track, we have dealt with some of the most difficult issues we have touched upon almost all of them, we have solved many of them and we are close to resolving some other issues."

status_message: United Nations Secretary-General António Guterres stressed, today, the importance of empowering women and girls to take part in the building of inclusive and resilient societies. Mr. Guterres was addressing the Security Council for the first time during a ministerial-level debate on conflict prevention.

In his first remarks to the Security Council today, United Nations Secretary-General António Guterres underlined that conflict prevention is "not merely a priority, but the priority." Mr. Guterres told the Council – which held a ministerial-level debate on "conflict prevention and sustaining peace" – that by restoring trust between governments, citizens and amongst Member States, conflict can be prevented and avoided. He noted that doing this would "save lives, reduce suffering and give hope to millions." 
Read more: http://bit.ly/2icHj9m

United Nations Secretary-General-designate António Guterres today announced the appointment of Nigeria's Minister of Environment, Amina J. Mohammed, as the next UN Deputy Secretary-General, in a triple-appointment of women to top UN posts. The other appointments are that of Brazilian diplomat Maria Luiza Ribeiro Viotti, who will assume the role of Chef de Cabinet, and the Republic of Korea's Kyung-wha Kang, a senior UN humanitarian official, who is expected to serve in a new role of Special Advisor on Policy. Mr. Guterres has previously indicated that ensuring gender parity and geographical diversity in UN appointments will be a priority of his. The appointments were announced at a press briefing by the Secretary-General's Spokesperson. Mr. Guterres will assume office on 1 January 2017, succeeding Ban Ki-moon whose tenure ends on 31 December 2016. http://bit.ly/2hTftz8

Last week, a water capture and distribution project was launched in Gressier, #Haiti by the head of the UN Stabilization Mission in the country (MINUSTAH), Sandra Honoré. 
Funded by the UN Mission, the $80,000 venture will supply water through nearly 5,000 metres of underground pipes to 12 kiosks spread across the surrounding communities in the Gressier commune. Designed to help Haiti and the United Nations fight cholera, it will enable 60,000 people's access to clean water on a daily basis.

The United Nations General Assembly today, 12 December 2016, paid tribute to outgoing Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon, for his "dedication and never-tiring service to humanity." Addressing the delegates, the President of the General Assembly Peter Thomson saluted Mr. Ban's unwavering "determination to ensure that the United Nations was always a resolute force for global good," and his service "at the front-line of trouble spots and at international summits alike."   #UNGA

status_message: Outgoing UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon has described the responsibility entrusted to him ten years ago as "a great privilege of a lifetime." Mr. Ban was speaking during a special ceremony in the UN General Assembly today, 12 December 2016, during which the Assembly paid tribute to him for his service, described by the General Assembly President Peter Thomson as "unwavering." In the speech - his final as the UN chief to the 193 Member States - Mr. Ban affectionately recounted his childhood memories of the UN, noting that its power - demonstrated through global solidarity - "was never abstract or academic" to him. Reflecting on his decade-long tenure, he highlighted the focus on people's dignity and rights, peace and progress. Mr. Ban will step down on 31 December 2016, to be succeeded by António Guterres, who was sworn in as the 9th Secretary-General shortly after the tribute ceremony. http://bit.ly/2hwyICN
link_name: Outgoing UN chief: Steering the world body "has been a great p...

On 12 December 2016, António Guterres will be sworn in as the next United Nations Secretary-General. In his vision for the post, Mr. Guterres - a former Prime Minister of Portugal and UN High Commissioner for Refugees - has said that the world body is uniquely placed to connect the dots to overcome global challenges and further strengthen the nexus between peace and security, sustainable development and human rights policies.

Read more: http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=55778

Upholding human rights is in the interest of all and are at the heart of the work and identify of the United Nations, Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon said in his message on #HumanRightsDay, calling on the international community to "stand up for someone's right today, tomorrow and every day."
link_name: 'Stand up for someone's rights today,' UN urges on Human Rights Day

status_message: Top stories from the UN News Centre, during the week of  5 - 9 December 2016, featuring: Secretary-General Ban's call for solidarity with refugees; support on the ground: a new outlook for Libya, and $22.2 billion for the 92.8 million vulnerable people in 2017.

The Special Adviser to the UN Special Envoy for Syria, Jan Egeland, has reiterated the need for at least 48 hours' ceasefire to allow aid to be delivered to Syrians in need. Mr. Egeland was speaking to the press following the conclusion, in Geneva on 8 December, of the weekly Humanitarian Taskforce meeting on Syria.  He also said the Syrian Government had approved humanitarian access to 800,000 civilians, including those in eastern Aleppo, following months of besiegement. http://bit.ly/2gpyZ8t

status_message:
While the influence of Da'esh has been reduced, the Libyan government does not yet have authority over the entire country, according to the UN envoy for the country, Martin Kobler. Mr. Kobler, who is the Special Representative of the Secretary-General and head of the UN Support Mission in Libya (UNSMIL) was speaking to the UN News Centre about the progress in security and the main challenges facing Libya, shortly after briefing the Security Council, which today issued a press statement on the situation in Libya. 

For more http://bit.ly/2hbMmIa

Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon has urged the international community to "build a bridge" for the 65 million refugees around the world, instead of erecting walls, noting, "we're all same human beings." Mr. Ban said this while visiting a refugee-run restaurant in Vienna, Austria on 8 December 2016, as a part of the UN's  'TOGETHER' Campaign. The establishment, Habibi & Hawara, has 12 employees, mainly from war-torn Syria.

Read more http://bit.ly/2gg9Eeb

Almost one year since the signing of the Libyan political agreement on 17 December 2015, the fight against terrorism has produced "good results" in the country's major cities, a senior UN official has said. Briefing the UN Security Council today, 6 December 2016,  Special Representative for the UN Secretary-General and head of the UN Support Mission in Libya (UNSMIL), Martin Kobler outlined the gains in the fight against terrorism, the challenges faced, as well as the outlook for Libya in 2017. Stating that more needs to be done to achieve further stability and economic recovery in the war-torn country, Mr. Kobler also emphasised the need for UNSMIL to return its operations to Libya "in a phased way" once security concerns are "adequately addressed and mitigated". http://bit.ly/2g6BPAT

Against the backdrop of "immense global suffering and fear," the UN Global Humanitarian Appeal for 2017 has identified funding needs of $22.2 billion, some 700 per cent higher than the UN's first inter-agency appeal 25 years ago in 1992. Launching the appeal in Geneva today (5 December), UN relief chief, Stephen O'Brien told reporters that funding for 2017 will be translated into "concrete actions," including but not limited to food, medical and psychological support, to aid nearly 93 million most vulnerable people in conflict-torn regions. http://bit.ly/2g2ZCNn

"The scale of humanitarian crises today is greater than at any time since the United Nations was founded," said UN Emergency Relief Coordinator Stephen O'Brien, launching the Global Humanitarian Overview 2017 in Geneva, Switzerland, according to a press release from OCHA.

"Not in living memory have so many people needed our support and solidarity to survive and live in safety and dignity," he said, noting that humanitarian response plans in 33 countries aim to reach 93 million people in need.

"Imagine – having your child rushed to an unsanitary basement and being operated on without anesthesia – these are conditions in Eastern Aleppo," said Special Advisor Jan Egeland on the humanitarian plight in Syria's Aleppo.

Read more: http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=55697

On the desperate medical situation, Special Advisor Jan Egeland reported that conditions are so bad that life-saving operations have to be conducted in basements and without anesthesia – the medical element that prevents patients from feeling severe, intolerable pain during the medical procedure.
link_name: Syria: With winter closing in, UN envoys highlight humanitarian urgency of situation in Aleppo

status_message: UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon has expressed deep regret for the loss and suffering caused by the cholera epidemic in Haiti, and apologised on behalf of the world body. Speaking at UN Headquarters in New York on 1 December 2016, the UN chief also outlined the Organization's future strategies for tackling the disease and helping Haitians rebuild their lives. Calling for solidarity from the international community, Mr. Ban encouraged Member States to "do the right thing for the Haitian people and our United Nations". Full story available from http://bit.ly/2h06boG
link_name: Ban apologises; calls for solidarity to "do what is right" for...

status_message:
The UN will reinforce efforts to help the fight against cholera in Haiti, according to Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon, in a message shared with Haitians, in Creole, one of the Caribbean nation's official languages. In the message, the UN chief also expressed, on behalf of the world body, regret for the suffering of the Haitian people in relation to the outbreak and flagged strategies for the way ahead. Mr. Ban also emphasized that the United Nations will "do the utmost" to help affected Haitians rebuild their lives.

For more, http://bit.ly/2gdsQdd
link_name: UN chief: We will "do the utmost" in tackling cholera in Haiti

status_message: "The world has made tremendous progress in the global effort to end AIDS, but the fight is far from over – especially for children and adolescents," said UNICEF Executive Director Anthony Lake in a news release. "Every two minutes, another adolescent – most likely a girl – will be infected with HIV. If we want to end AIDS, we need to recapture the urgency this issue deserves and redouble our efforts to reach every child and every adolescent," he added.
link_name: On World AIDS Day, UNICEF warns of sharp rise in new HIV infections among adolescents if progress stalls

Up to 16,000 people have fled in recent days, as fighting intensified in the eastern part of the city. Warning that thousands more civilians could go on to fall victim to the escalating conflict, OCHA urged all related parties to prioritise the restoration of "basic humanity in Syria" over gaining military advantage. "Without doubt, unsustainable transport brings numerous challenges. For example, the transport sector is responsible for about one quarter of greenhouse gas emissions. Also, more than 1.25 million are killed annually in road traffic accidents – sadly to say that 90 per cent [of these] happen in developing countries," the UN Under-Secretary-General for Economic and Social Affairs, Wu Hongbo, said today at a press briefing in the Turkmen capital of Ashgabat, ahead of the start of the Global #SustainableTransport.

The third Secretary-General of the United Nations, U Thant of Myanmar, passed away on this day 42 years ago, in 1974. Serving as a diplomat for Burma (now known as Myanmar), he was appointed the world's top diplomat, in an acting capacity, following the untimely death of Dag Hammarskjöld in 1961. The following year saw the General Assembly appoint him to the role for a full term. He was subsequently re-appointed to a second term in 1966. Coming soon: a personal and up-close look at his work at the world body in the next issue of the Character Sketches series by UN veteran Brian Urquhart http://bit.ly/2gpwx2B

Space applications related to telecommunications and global navigation can play a vital role in supporting disaster risk reduction, response and recovery efforts, a senior United Nations official said today at the UN forum on space as a socio-economic driver for sustainable development under way in Dubai.

Read more: http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=55632

"During the [2015-2016] period, stronger improvements have been made on ICT use than access, mainly as a result of strong growth in mobile-broadband uptake globally. This has allowed an increasing number of people, in particular from the developing world, to join the information society and benefit from the many services and applications provided through the Internet," explained Brahima Sanou, Director of ITU Telecommunication Development Bureau, responsible for the report.

Preparations are underway between the United Nations and Sierra Nevada Corporation's Space Systems (SNC) for a first ever collaborative space mission in 2021, with SNC's Dream Chaser spacecraft. At a high level forum in Dubai, UAE, about Space as a Driver for Socio-Economic Sustainable Development, SNC Corporate Vice President Mark Sirangelo spoke to UN News Centre about the company's collaboration with the world body on its maiden space mission.

Women make teams stronger and more creative, says NASA's Gale Allen...

Women and minorities can play a significant role in space science, making teams stronger and more creative, according to the United States space agency (NASA) Deputy Scientist, Gale Allen. Speaking to UN News Centre at a high level forum in Dubai, UAE, about Space as a driver for socio-economic sustainable development, Ms. Allen also explained how education impacts gender equality in academia.

Meanwhile ... the UN has named former astronaut Scott Kelly as 'Champion for Space' http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=55618

"This appalling attack on worshippers is an atrocity," said Pernille Kardel, the Secretary-General's Deputy Special Representative for Afghanistan, in a statement to the press.

According to the UN Assistance Mission in Afghanistan (UNAMA), a suicide attacker detonated his body-borne improvised explosive device at the Baqer-ul Ulom mosque in the nation's capital, deliberately targeting worshippers from the country's Shia Muslim community, which had a particularly large congregation to observe Arbaeen, a commemoration on the 40th day after Ashura.
link_name: Afghanistan: UN mission condemns killing of civilians in Kabul mosque attack

Today (18 November), over 45 climate-vulnerable countries have declared robust action plans to implement the Paris Agreement. The joint efforts include the transformation of energy, transport, and other sectors, as well as safeguarding the well-being of the indigenous, disadvantaged groups of the society. The Head of UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), Patricia Espinosa, has welcomed the adaptation of this declaration.

status_message: Top stories from the UN News Centre, during the week of 14 - 18 November 2016, featuring: the 22nd UN Conference on Climate Change, displacement of children in Central African Republic, and humanitarian assessment of Haiti.

The Office of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) urged the Myanmar Government to immediately allow humanitarian actors to resume the life-saving activities for some 160,000 civilians, which were suspended on 9 October.

Meanwhile, the Office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR) reported that tens of thousands of people have fled their homes amid a security operation triggered by armed attacks on border posts in October. Residents, including members of the Rohingya minority and other Muslim communities, are reported to have suffered serious human rights violations including torture, rape and sexual assault, summary executions, and the destruction of mosques and homes.
link_name: UN refugee agency urges Myanmar to grant aid workers access to northern Rakhine state

In interview with UN News Centre, Petteri Taalas, Secretary-General of World Meteorological Organization talks about the real-world impact of extreme weather and global temperature rise.

"One degree does not sound like a big number if you compare the temperate over a couple of days but globally [over a long period of time] it means that we have seen an increase in the amount of disasters related to the weather. It means that we have observed more heat waves, for example, in Kuwait, the temperature hit 54 degrees Celsius last summer and there have been devastating heat waves in many continents."

Read more: http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=55564

status_message: "Today in Haiti marks the first day of a vaccination campaign against cholera in areas ravaged by Hurricane Matthew," Stéphane Dujarric, the spokesman for the UN Secretary-General, told reporters in New York, noting that the campaign is supported by the Pan American Health Organization/World Health Organization (PAHO/WHO), the UN Children's Fund (UNICEF) and others. "The target population is estimated at 820,000 people over one year of age. Activities will focus on municipalities most vulnerable to cholera outbreaks in the two southern departments of Grand'Anse and Sud, where there have been significant destruction of water and other supply systems," Mr. Dujarric said.

Haiti:
Jeremie, one of the areas hit the hardest by Hurricane Matthew in Haiti, is in urgent need of clean water to cope with the ongoing cholera epidemic. As UN agencies endeavour to provide humanitarian assistance to thousands of Haitians affected by the hurricane, the cholera response remains at the core of the Organization's work in the Caribbean nation. 

In Jeremie, a new UN-funded water plant now provides 300,000 litres of potable water to 20,000 people per day.

The United Nations envoy for Yemen, Ould Cheikh Ahmed, has said the rejection of his roadmap to end the conflict in the country indicated "the failure of the political elite in Yemen to overcome its differences and put public interest over personal interests." The Special Envoy said, "The time has come for parties to know that there is no peace without concessions and no security without agreements." He called on the Security Council to show support for his plan and bring an immediate ceasefire to the country. Mr. Cheikh Ahmed said after 18 months of fighting and a "humanitarian situation which is no longer humane" the question remained how long the Yemeni people would be "hostage to personal and random political decisions."

status_message:
In Geneva, Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon spoke to reporters. While calling for an end to the conflicts in Syria and elsewhere, he reflected on his tenure as the UN chief.   

-The United Nations, during his period, has paid more attention to preventive diplomacy.
-He has appointed the most Special Envoys, Special Advisors and Special Representatives.
-At the UN, too many good ideas needlessly die from insisting on "unanimity" when all that is needed is "consensus" for progress.
-The next Secretary-General should have far-reaching vision, compassion and flexibility.
-He expressed regret on two issues - one on sexual abuse and exploitation by UN peacekeepers and staff and the other on the cholera incident in Haiti. 

Read more about Ban Ki-moon's press conference in Geneva http://bit.ly/2dMi68P
link_name: UN Secretary-General speaks at a press conference in Geneva

status_message:
Bringing the #ParisAgreement on climate change ever closer to its entry into force, India today joined the new global accord at the United Nations Headquarters in New York and became the 62nd country to deposit its legal instrument of ratification. The Agreement, which calls on countries to combat climate change and limit global temperature rise to well below 2 degrees Celsius, will take effect 30 days after at least 55 countries, responsible for 55 per cent of global greenhouse gas emissions, deposit their instruments of ratification.

With today's action by India, which accounts for 4.1 per cent of the emissions, the Agreement only needs slightly more than 3 percentage points to reach the 55 per cent threshold.

Some 3.5 million school-aged Iraqi children are missing out on education, which means they are at increased risk of early marriage, child labour and recruitment into armed groups. About one million school-aged children are internally displaced, and 70 per cent of them have lost an entire year of school.

Fewer than 30 doctors left in war-torn Aleppo, UN health agency warns -- http://bit.ly/2djMRz2

"There has been a reduction in the number of health workers able to stay at their posts, and those who did are exhausted, drained physically and emotionally," Dr. Rick Brennan, the Director of Emergency Risk Management and Humanitarian Response of the World Health Organization (WHO), told reporters in Geneva. "The work they are doing is beyond heroic. For them to stay at their post under those conditions deserves unending admiration and respect," he added.

status_message:
In a statement issued following former Israeli President Shimon Peres's passing on 27 September 2016, UN Secretary-General, Ban Ki-moon recalled the late Peres's speech at the UN in 2001, when he said:

"The time has come to comprehend that the real triumph is in the harvest of peace, not in the seeds of another war. When we replace war maps with peace maps, we will discover the differences were minimal. The wars were appalling. We shall see that the promised land could have become the land of promise a long time ago." 

Here's an excerpt from the the speech...

For more on the Secretary-General's tribute: http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=55145#.V-x3wJgrLic

"He worked tirelessly for a two-state solution that would enable Israel to live securely and harmoniously with the Palestinians and the wider region, a commitment duly recognized when he shared the 1994 Nobel Peace Prize with Yitzhak Rabin and Yasser Arafat," UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon said, also noting that Mr. Peres was also a good partner of the UN, eager to see Israel contribute to the work of the international community.

Their story is the subject of the film "Watani, My Homeland," which is now streaming on PBS as the documentary "Children of Syria."

status_message: As the United Nations relief wing warned today that soaring temperatures and dwindling medical supplies are deepening the woes of some two million people trapped by fighting in and around Aleppo, the world body kept up its call for an immediate halt to the hostilities and, at a minimum, a two-day weekly humanitarian pause so the city's heavily damaged water and electrical systems can be repaired.

"If the heart is great, that man remains great under all circumstances, rich or poor, large or small," Muhammad Ali said during his address to the UN Special Committee against Apartheid at the United Nations in 1978.

Named a United Nations Messenger of Peace in 1998, Muhammad Ali travelled the globe to support children and others caught up in conflict, and to promote reconciliation between people and nations.

This year's theme is "Honouring our Heroes," a nod to the 125,000 military, police and civilian staff who serve in 16 peacekeeping operations around the world. The deployment is the largest in UN history.

Two days ago we brought you the story of Ibrahim, a Syrian refugee and pro athlete. After losing his leg in a bomb attack, he claimed asylum in Greece. And despite losing his home, and having to cope with his disability, he refused to give up. 

On April 27th, Ibrahim carried the Olympic torch through the Eleonas Accommodation site in western Athens, where 1,500 refugees and migrants are being hosted.

status_message: Top Syrian athlete Ibrahim Al-Hussein fled the war two years go after sustaining a life-changing injury. Granted asylum in Greece in 2014, he has stuck to his rigorous training schedule in Athens - all while working a 10-hour-overnight shift in a café. Now this inspirational refugee is being recognized for his talent and bravery, courtesy of one of Greece's highest honours.

status_message: World Water Day is marked on 22 March every year to celebrate water and focus attention on the importance of freshwater and addressing water-related challenges. This year's theme is "Water and Jobs". #WorldWaterDay

status_message: On the eve of World Water Day, UNICEF is warning about the safety concerns due to climate change, as water becomes scarce during droughts, flooding damages water and sewage treatment facilities, and water-borne diseases, such as cholera and diarrhoea, spread more quickly.
link_name: #Climatechain: UN to launch campaign illustrating water-environment-climate change link

status_message: "Persons with disabilities, including those with Down syndrome, are more than persons in need of assistance; they are agents of change who can drive progress across society," the UN chief said in his message for the Day, which is observed annually on 21 March.  #WDSD16

status_message:
A young man wants to smoke a cigarette but does not have the money to buy a pack.

"He has a slave girl, he goes and sells her to another man, and he gets enough money for a pack of cigarettes. That's it. She is the value of a pack of cigarettes," said Zainab Bangura, the Secretary-General's Special Representative on Sexual Violence in Conflict.

This is the story of countless Yazidi women living in Iraq who have been sold into slavery by ISIL and other terrorist groups, which are using sexual violence as a central aspect of their ideology.
link_name: FEATURE: Sold for a packet of cigarettes – UN envoy fights to help women suffering sexual violence

The world's indigenous youth are suffering from a worrying trend of suicide and self-harm, according to the United Nations. The UN News Centre spoke with some of the participants at the recent UN Permanent Forum on Indigenous Issues and heard their personal insights into the causes of this scourge affecting indigenous youth and the steps that can be taken to end it.

The world's indigenous youth are suffering from a worrying trend of suicide and self-harm, according to the United Nations.

A new earthquake measuring 7.3 magnitude struck #Nepal today, just as emergency responders were racing against time to reach affected populations two weeks after another quake hit the country killing thousands.
link_name: New quake hits Nepal as UN races to deliver aid to those affected

status_message:
The Mediterranean migrant crisis calls for collective action focused on the immediate need to save lives or else it will represent "a moral failure of the first order," one that undermines international law and security, a top United Nations migration official warned today.

More: http://bit.ly/1JCqcWN

More than 27,000 applicants applied for some 200 teaching jobs for the coming academic year in the Gaza Strip, where unemployment has now reached nearly 44 per cent, making it one of the world's most unstable economies, UNRWA has confirmed.

More children in #Yemen are at risk of dying from hunger and lack of health services than from bombs and bullets, UNICEF has warned amid ongoing fighting across the Gulf country.

status_message: The number of irregular migrants crossing the Bay of Bengal has almost doubled over the past year amid a dangerous uptick in human smuggling and trafficking across the region, according to a new report from UNHCR.

status_message: Iran has witnessed a surge in executions over the past two years. More than 340 persons, including at least six political prisoners and seven women, were reportedly executed since January 2015.

status_message: 2015 is a critical year for the UN's Sustainable Development agenda. Renowned economist and UN expert Jeffrey Sachs tells us why.

UN Special Representative Zainab Bangura listed examples of the horrors suffered by women, including one who had been temporarily married over 20 times and, after each occasion, forced to undergo surgery to repair her virginity.

status_message:
"From West Africa to Central Asia, we see how international drug trafficking jeopardizes peacebuilding efforts and bolsters terrorist groups," Deputy Secretary-General Jan Eliasson declared in remarks delivered at this morning's High-Level Thematic Debate in support of the 2016 special session of the General Assembly on the issue.

During a three-day visit to Nauru, members of the UN Subcommittee on the Prevention of Torture (SPT) visited Nauru's police station and prison, as well as the Regional Processing Center (RPC) for asylum-seekers, a large facility comprising three separate units housing men, women and families with children who have been attempting to reach Australia.
